title: Bioacoustics work in the Barthelmess Lab
text:
Biodiversity
Measuring and monitoring biodiversity are crucial if we hope to stem the rampant biodiversity loss currently facing our world.
This document provides an overview and instructions on our (and by “our” I mean the folks conducting research in the Barthelmess Lab at St. Lawrence University, aka the SLU Mammal Crew) deploy workflow for using AudioMoth acoustic recorders as one means of measuring and monitoring biodiversity in the North Country.

title: 1  An introduction to Sound
text:
1.1 Introduction
To fully understand how we can use bioacoustic recording to measure and monitor biodiversity, we first need to understand some principles about sound and how sound is digitally recorded.

title: 1  An introduction to Sound
text:
1.2 Some Definitions
Three terms we need to familiarize ourselves with stem from the work of soundscape ecologists (Villanueva-Rivera et al. 2011) , and can be defined as follows:

Biophony = Sounds generated by living organisms and/or their activity. Examples include bird song, beaver tail slaps, woodpecker foraging.
Anthrophony = sounds generated by human activity. Examples include traffic noise, sirens, fireworks, gunfire etc.
Geophony = sounds generated by non-living earth features. Examples include wind, streamflow, and thunder.

title: 1  An introduction to Sound
section: 1.3 Sound and digital recording of sound
text:
1.3 Sound and digital recording of sound
Sound is propagated as a wave through a medium (air, water). When a simple sound is emitted as a pure tone, it can be depicted as a sine wave. In Figure 1.1, we see one and a half wavelengths of a simple sound wave. The height of the wave is its amplitude and determines how loud the sound is. The width of one wave is the wavelength. Low-pitched sounds have longer wavelengths than do higher pitched sounds.








Figure 1.1: Example of a sound wave





In Figure 1.2, you can see two sound waves depicted, one in black and the other in blue.






Which of the two waves in the figure below has higher volume? Check for answer





The black wave is louder than the blue wave because it has a higher amplitude











Figure 1.2: Example of two waves with the same wavelength but different amplitude.





The pitch (in music think of the note - high or low sounding) of a sound is determined by its frequency, the number of waves emitted per unit of time (typically seconds). Long waves are slower to propagate and thus have lower frequencies than do short sound waves. In other words, high-pitched sounds have a high frequency and low-pitched sounds have low frequency.
In Figure 1.3, we again see two sound waves. One is higher in pitch than the other.






Which of the two waves in the figure below has higher pitch? Check for answer





The blue wave is higher pitched than the black wave because it has a higher frequency











Figure 1.3: Example of two waves with the same amplitude but different frequencies.
